results.title: On the loose: three stories about leaving school
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Lyn Norfor and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: A trilogy about three teenagers seeking their independence in the outside world after finishing school. The three stories show the problems faced by a generation leaving school in the mid 1980s - boredom with school (“Exit Eddie Leech”), sexual pressures in the workplace (“Ring of Confidence”), and keeping a job (“Beginner’s luck”).
results.title_for_label: On the loose: three stories about leaving school
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jane Oehr, Lyn Norfor and New South Wales. Dept. of Health

results.title: Understanding cancer (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Roger Hudson, Jim Dale and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: By considering two basic questions, what is cancer? and what is the cause of cancer?, this program attempts to lay at rest many of the myths about this disease. A very comprehensive coverage of the nature of cancer, epidemiology and carcinogens. Presented by Professor Richard Fox, Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research, University of Sydney.

results.title: The Humble force
results.creator_credit: Geoff Steven, John Maynard, New Zealand National Film Unit and Phase Three Films
results.brief_description: Beyond the Great Wall of China lies “the power of the ancient dynasties and the new red star of communism”. This film explores the juxtaposition of China’s ancient heritage with its continuing advances into technology, communism and subtle trends into westernisation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Steven, John Maynard, New Zealand National Film Unit and Phase Three Films

results.title: A Killing rain (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Taylor, United Nations Environment Programme and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Acid rain is one aspect of environmental pollution discussed at the Public Hearing in London in 1982. This program travels from Scotland to Scandinavia to West Germany to uncover background causes and the effects of this major pollution problem of the 80s.

results.title: Victoria : The First 150 Years
results.creator_credit: Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria
results.brief_description: An overview of Victoria covering its history, culture and landscape. Gold, sport, bushfires and rural Victoria are amongst the subjects covered and there is also a significant use of historical film footage in this description of Victoria.

results.title: The Bamboo Curtain Falls
results.brief_description: This is the second part of a two part documentary that looks at the mysterious story of Tibet. It is the story about a country unseen by Europeans until early this century, of its destruction by invading Chinese in 1950, and the flight into India of the Dalai Lama with 100,000 Tibetans.

results.title: Couldn't be fairer
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, British Broadcasting Corporation and O'Rourke and Associates Filmakers
results.brief_description: This is a devastating account of the Aboriginal land rights battle in Queensland. It reveals white Australians at their most beer-sodden and hypocritical. O’Rourke has captured scenes showing how racism and vulgarity, are alive and thriving in the Australian heartland! The film includes interviews by Mick Miller, chairman of the Queensland Aboriginal Land Council, with Joh Bjelke-Peterson and Russ Hinze.

results.title: Australian gazette. No. 3
results.brief_description: This reel consists of 7 magazine items, including snapshots of the Fitzroy Gardens, a trip to Seal Rock by boat, Kangaroos at Wilson’s Prom, beehives shot in close-up and some prize footage of a motorcycle race on a track around the outside of the Exhibition Buildings. There is also some surprising early experimental filming of Flinders Street, and traffic and crowds on Swanston Street. One amazing shot appears upside-down and then mid-way proceeds to turn upright and show the traffic and people travelling backwards. Footage is then sped up for a cable car ride down a main street. No credits available.

results.title: Victoria's welcome to press delegates
results.brief_description: Viscount Burnham is welcomed by S.S. Argyle, M.L.A. Chief Secretary of Victoria. Items of interest are pointed out, indicating Victoria’s development as a state including footage of Sir John Monash, development of the Hume Weir, Yallourn Open Cut mine, the Dandenong Ranges/Ferntree Gully, Yarra Glen, Camperdown, Rochester, the “Better Farming Train”, Bendigo, Geelong and Geelong Grammar, and Ballarat. Source: National Film and Sound Archive.
